start.speaker: Pixel
start.text: Level 7 - DICTIONARIES! The ultimate data organizer! üìö
start.followUp: Think of dictionaries as labeled treasure chests - every item has a name tag!

options.text: How are they different from lists?

dictVsList.speaker: Pixel
dictVsList.text: Lists use numbers (0, 1, 2...), dictionaries use names (health, mana, strength)!
dictVsList.codeExample:
# List - access by index
stats_list = [100, 50, 25]
health = stats_list[0]  # Which one is health again?

# Dictionary - access by name
stats_dict = {'health': 100, 'mana': 50, 'armor': 25}
health = stats_dict['health']  # Crystal clear!
dictVsList.followUp: Dictionaries make your code readable - no more guessing what index means what!

createDict.speaker: Pixel
createDict.text: Creating dictionaries is easy - use curly braces and key:value pairs!
createDict.codeExample:
# Empty dictionary
inventory = {}

# Character stats dictionary
player = {
    'name': 'Hero',
    'level': 1,
    'health': 100,
    'mana': 50,
    'experience': 0
}

# Item dictionary
sword = {
    'name': 'Iron Sword',
    'damage': 15,
    'durability': 100,
    'value': 50
}
createDict.followUp: Each key points to a value - like variable names for each piece of data!

accessDict.speaker: Pixel
accessDict.text: Access values using keys - like looking up stats on a character sheet!
accessDict.codeExample:
player = {
    'name': 'Shadow Knight',
    'level': 5,
    'health': 150,
    'skills': ['slash', 'block', 'charge']
}

# Access with brackets
name = player['name']  # 'Shadow Knight'
level = player['level']  # 5

# Access with get() - safer!
mana = player.get('mana', 0)  # Returns 0 if no mana key

# Access nested data
first_skill = player['skills'][0]  # 'slash'
accessDict.followUp: Use get() to avoid errors when a key might not exist!

options.text: How do I add or change values?

modifyDict.speaker: Pixel
modifyDict.text: Dictionaries are mutable - perfect for tracking changing game states!
modifyDict.codeExample:
player = {'name': 'Hero', 'level': 1, 'exp': 0}

# Change existing value
player['level'] = 2  # Level up!

# Add new key-value pair
player['class'] = 'Warrior'  # New attribute!
player['gold'] = 100

# Update multiple values at once
player.update({
    'health': 150,
    'mana': 75,
    'strength': 20
})

print(player)  # See all the changes!
modifyDict.followUp: Dictionaries grow with your game - add new attributes anytime!

removeKeys.speaker: Pixel
removeKeys.text: Remove keys when they're no longer needed - like using consumable items!
removeKeys.codeExample:
inventory = {
    'potion': 3,
    'elixir': 1,
    'bomb': 5,
    'key': 1
}

# Remove with del
del inventory['key']  # Used the key!

# Remove and get the value
elixirs = inventory.pop('elixir')  # Returns 1
print(f'Used {elixirs} elixir(s)')

# Remove if exists (safe)
inventory.pop('sword', None)  # No error if no sword

# Clear everything
# inventory.clear()  # Empty dictionary!
removeKeys.followUp: pop() is great - it removes AND returns the value!

dictMethods.speaker: Pixel
dictMethods.text: Dictionaries have powerful methods for game development!
dictMethods.codeExample:
player = {'name': 'Hero', 'level': 10, 'gold': 500}

# Get all keys
attributes = list(player.keys())
# ['name', 'level', 'gold']

# Get all values
values = list(player.values())
# ['Hero', 10, 500]

# Get key-value pairs
items = list(player.items())
# [('name', 'Hero'), ('level', 10), ('gold', 500)]

# Check if key exists
if 'level' in player:
    print(f'Level: {player['level']}')

# Loop through dictionary
for key, value in player.items():
    print(f'{key}: {value}')
dictMethods.followUp: These methods let you explore and manipulate your data structures!

nestedDict.speaker: Pixel
nestedDict.text: Nested dictionaries are perfect for complex game data - like full RPG characters!
nestedDict.followUp: Nested dictionaries can represent entire game worlds!

gameExamples.speaker: Pixel
gameExamples.text: Let's see dictionaries in action for real game systems!
gameExamples.followUp: Dictionaries are the backbone of game data management!

options.text: Can I convert between lists and dicts?

conversion.speaker: Pixel
conversion.text: You can convert between lists and dictionaries when needed!
conversion.codeExample:
# List of tuples to dictionary
items = [('sword', 1), ('shield', 1), ('potion', 5)]
inventory = dict(items)
# {'sword': 1, 'shield': 1, 'potion': 5}

# Two lists to dictionary
keys = ['health', 'mana', 'stamina']
values = [100, 50, 75]
stats = dict(zip(keys, values))
# {'health': 100, 'mana': 50, 'stamina': 75}

# Dictionary to lists
player = {'name': 'Hero', 'level': 10}
keys_list = list(player.keys())    # ['name', 'level']
values_list = list(player.values()) # ['Hero', 10]
conversion.followUp: Converting between structures gives you flexibility!

practiceChallenge.speaker: Pixel
practiceChallenge.text: Epic Challenge: Build a complete inventory system with dictionaries!
practiceChallenge.followUp: Track item quantities, categories, and implement a shop system!

options.text: Dictionaries are perfect for game data!

lessonComplete.speaker: Pixel
lessonComplete.text: üéä LEVEL 7 COMPLETE! You've mastered data organization! üóÇÔ∏è
lessonComplete.followUp: Dictionaries let you build complex game systems - inventories, stats, quests, everything!
